questions.text: All of the following agents are used for decalcification, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Decalcification agents: These are used to soften hard tissues like bone and teeth by removing calcium salts.
    • 10% Nitric acid (Option A): Rapid action, commonly used decalcifying agent.
    • 5% Trichloroacetic acid (Option B): Acts slowly, preserves tissue well.
    • EDTA (Ethylenediamine tetra-acetic acid) (Option C): Slow decalcifier but best for preserving tissue structure.
  • Fixative agents: Used to preserve tissue architecture.
    • Picric acid (Option D): Used as a fixative, not a decalcifying agent.

Key points:

  • Some combinations commonly used for tissue fixation are:
    • Bouin's fluid (formalin, acetic acid and picric acid)
    • Formal sublimate (formalin and mercuric chloride)
    • Helly's fluid (formalin, mercuric chloride and potassium dichromate)
    • Zenker's fluid (acetic acid, mercuric chloride and potassium dichromate)
  • For decalcification, several decalcifying agents are used, namely
    • 10% nitric acid
    • 5% trichloroacetic acid
    • Ethylenediamine tetra acetic acid (EDTA)

Additional Points:

  • Decalcification allows cutting of hard tissues in histology by softening them.
  • Formalin is often combined with other fixatives like acetic acid and mercuric chloride to preserve tissues for histological study.

Why not others:

  • Option A (Nitric acid): A commonly used decalcifying agent.
  • Option B (Trichloroacetic acid): Also used for decalcification.
  • Option C (EDTA): Slow but effective decalcifying agent.
  • Option D (Picric acid): Used as a fixative, not for decalcification.

Key Takeaway: Decalcifying agents like nitric acid, trichloroacetic acid, and EDTA are essential for preparing hard tissues in histology, while picric acid is primarily used as a fixative.

choices.text: He is known as father of histology
He was the first scientist to observe capillaries under microscope

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about the scientist Marcelo Malpighi?
questions.solution:
• Marcelo Malpighi:
    • Known as the Father of Histology, due to his pioneering work in microscopic anatomy.
    • He was the first to observe capillaries under a microscope, confirming the connection between arteries and veins in the circulatory system.
    • He did not introduce the concept of tissues (Option C). This was introduced by Xavier Bichat, who is regarded as the father of modern histology for classifying tissues based on their structure.

Additional Points:

  • Malpighi used microscopes for biological studies, but did not invent the first microscope; this was developed by Hans and Zacharias Jansen.

Why not others:

  • Option A (Father of Histology): Correct, Malpighi is known for this.
  • Option B (Invented first microscope): False, Hans and Jansen are credited with this.
  • Option D (Observed capillaries under a microscope): Correct, Malpighi was the first to document capillaries.

Key Takeaway: Marcelo Malpighi contributed greatly to histology and microscopy but did not introduce the concept of tissues, which is attributed to Xavier Bichat.

questions.text: All of the following structures are lined by the simple cuboidal epithelium, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Simple cuboidal epithelium:
    • Found in structures like thyroid follicles, kidney tubules, and the pigmented layer of the retina.
    • Functions: Primarily secretion and absorption.
  • Option A (Ducts of sweat glands): Lined by stratified cuboidal epithelium which offers more protection, not simple cuboidal.
  • Option B (Thyroid follicles): Lined by simple cuboidal epithelium, involved in thyroid hormone secretion.
  • Option C (Kidney tubules): Lined by simple cuboidal epithelium, functioning in filtration and reabsorption.
  • Option D (Pigmented layer of retina): Lined by simple cuboidal epithelium, crucial for light absorption and protection of the photoreceptors.

Why not others?

  • Ducts of sweat glands (Option A) are lined by stratified cuboidal epithelium, not simple cuboidal.
  • The other options (B, C, D) all involve structures lined by simple cuboidal epithelium.

Key takeaway:
The simple cuboidal epithelium lines structures mainly involved in secretion and absorption, while ducts of sweat glands are lined by stratified cuboidal epithelium for protection.

choices.text: Lumen is smaller than mucus acinus

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about serous acinus as compare to mucus acinus, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Serous Acinus:
    • Secretes thin watery fluid (Option A).
    • Contains zymogen granules, not mucigen droplets (hence, Option B is false).
    • Lumen is smaller than mucus acinus (Option C).
    • Example: Parotid gland (Option D).
  • Mucous Acinus:
    • Secretes thick viscous fluid.
    • Contains mucigen droplets.

Differences between serous and mucous acini:

Why not others?

  • Option A: Serous acinus secretes thin watery fluid.
  • Option C: Serous acinus has a smaller lumen compared to mucus acinus.
  • Option D: Parotid gland is a classic example of a serous acinus.

Key takeaway:

Serous acini produce thin watery secretions with zymogen granules and have a smaller lumen compared to mucus acini, which secrete thick mucus.

questions.text: Which of the following connective tissue present in the marked structure?
questions.solution:
• Marked Structure: Dermis of the skin.
  • Connective Tissue Present: Dense irregular connective tissue (Answer: D).
    • Collagen fibers are densely packed and oriented in all directions, providing strength and resistance to stress in various directions.

Types of Connective Tissue:

  • Loose Areolar Connective Tissue (Option B):
    • Vascular and flexible; fibers are loosely arranged.
    • Serves as packing material (e.g., subperitoneal tissue).
  • Dense Regular Connective Tissue (Option C):
    • Collagen fibers densely packed in an orderly manner.
    • Found in tendons and ligaments.
  • Reticular Connective Tissue (Option A):
    • Modified loose connective tissue made of reticular fibers.
    • Provides an architectural framework (e.g., stroma of lymphoid organs).

Why not others?

  • Option A: Reticular connective tissue is loosely arranged, unlike the densely packed fibers in the dermis.
  • Option B: Loose areolar connective tissue lacks the dense packing characteristic of the dermis.
  • Option C: Dense regular connective tissue has orderly fiber alignment, which is not the case in the dermis.

Key Takeaway:

The dermis contains dense irregular connective tissue, characterized by densely packed collagen fibers arranged in multiple directions, providing structural support and strength to the skin.

choices.text: Volume of myofibrils more than sarcoplasm
Few mitochodria with extensive sarcoplasmic reticulum
Broad diameter with well defined straitions

questions.text: Which of the following is statement is true about the red muscle fibres (type I)?
questions.solution:
• True Statement: Rich in myoglobin and cytochrome (Answer: C).
    • Type I (Red Muscle Fibres) are specialized for aerobic metabolism, providing endurance and resistance to fatigue.

Comparison of Muscle Fiber Types:

Red Muscle Fibers (Type I):

  • Rich in myoglobin and cytochrome, giving them a red color.
  • Narrow diameter with less defined striations; nuclei not always at the periphery.
  • Volume of sarcoplasm is greater than myofibrils.
  • Numerous mitochondria; sarcoplasmic reticulum is less extensive.
  • Slow and continuous tonic contraction, making them not easily fatigued.
  • Predominantly found in postural muscles (e.g., brachialis, soleus).

White Muscle Fibers (Type II):

  • Less myoglobin and cytochrome, hence white in color.
  • Broad diameter with well-defined striations; nuclei located at the periphery.
  • Volume of myofibrils is greater than sarcoplasm.
  • Few mitochondria; extensive sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  • Fast and rapid phasic contraction, making them easily fatigued.
  • Found in muscles responsible for sharp active movements (e.g., extraocular muscles, gastrocnemius).

Why not others?

  • Option A: Incorrect as red fibers have more sarcoplasm than myofibrils.
  • Option B: Red fibers have numerous mitochondria, not few, and less extensive sarcoplasmic reticulum.
  • Option D: Red fibers are narrower and have less defined striations.

Key Takeaway:

Type I (red muscle fibers) are characterized by their rich content of myoglobin and cytochrome, enabling aerobic metabolism for sustained contractions, primarily found in postural muscles.

choices.text: Thickening of tunica intima and calcification of tunica media
Loss of elasticity of tunica media and accumulation of lipid in the myointimal cells
Thickening of tunica intima and accumulation of lipid in the myointimal cells
Formation of fibrofatty plaques in tunica intima and calcification of tunica media

questions.text: What is artherosclerosis?
questions.solution:
• Atherosclerosis is defined as the formation of fibrofatty plaques in the tunica intima and calcification of the tunica media (Answer: D).

Characteristics of Atherosclerosis:

  • Thickening of Tunica Intima:
    • Migration and proliferation of smooth muscle cells from the tunica media.
    • Accumulation of lipids in myointimal cells and macrophages, leading to plaque formation.
  • Formation of Fibrofatty Plaques:
    • Development of atheromas (fibrofatty plaques) within the tunica intima that narrow the arterial lumen.
  • Calcification:
    • Occurs in the tunica media, contributing to arteriosclerosis, resulting in loss of elasticity.
  • Age-related Changes:
    • Thickening and lipid accumulation can lead to significant changes in artery structure, impacting blood flow and pressure.
  • Health Implications:
    • Atherosclerosis is a leading cause of cardiovascular diseases, increasing the risk of heart attack and stroke.
    • It may lead to aneurysm formation due to weakened arterial walls, which can be life-threatening if ruptured.

Why not others?

  • Option A: Incorrect; while there is thickening of the intima, it does not fully describe the plaque formation.
  • Option B: Incorrect; this option highlights loss of elasticity but does not mention plaque formation.
  • Option C: Incorrect; it mentions lipid accumulation but does not include the critical aspect of plaque formation.

Key Takeaway:

Atherosclerosis involves the formation of fibrofatty plaques and calcification within the arterial walls, leading to narrowing of the lumen, which poses significant risks for cardiovascular events.

questions.text: Match the following structures of blood vessels
questions.solution:
• Large Artery (1-Y): Well-developed tunica media containing elastic fibers allows for expansion and recoil during blood flow.
  • Medium Sized Artery (2-W): Features a thick tunica media with smooth muscle fibers, providing strength and flexibility.
  • Large Vein (3-X): Has a well-developed tunica adventitia with bundles of smooth muscle, supporting the vein structure.
  • Medium Sized Vein (4-Z): Characterized by a thin wall with a tunica media that contains fewer smooth muscle and elastic fibers, making it less robust.

Why Not Others:

  • A: Incorrect pairings; large artery and medium vein do not match the structural descriptions.
  • B: Misidentifies the characteristics of medium sized artery and vein.
  • D: Incorrectly pairs large artery and medium sized vein with descriptions that do not fit their structure.

Key Takeaways:

  • Large Artery: Rich in elastic fibers (Y), essential for maintaining blood pressure.
  • Medium Sized Artery: Thick with smooth muscle (W), allows for regulation of blood flow.
  • Large Vein: Thick adventitia with smooth muscle (X) for support.
  • Medium Sized Vein: Thin with few smooth muscle fibers (Z), making it more compliant.

questions.text: Given diagram is showing the histology of which of the following lymphoid organ?
questions.solution:
• The diagram depicts the thymus, characterized by:
    • Distinct lobules: Lymphoid tissue arranged in lobules, separated by connective tissue septae.
    • Outer cortex: Darkly stained with densely packed lymphocytes.
    • Inner medulla: Lightly stained, continuous across lobules, containing corpuscles of Hassall.
  • Identification of thymus:
  • The cortex is confined to one lobule, the medulla is continuous from one lobule to another. The medulla contains pink staining rounded masses called the corpuscles of Hassall.

Why Not Others:

  • A (Lymph Node): Contains a distinct outer cortex, inner medulla, and lymphatic follicles, which are not present in the thymus.
  • C (Palatine Tonsil): Features deep crypts and is covered by stratified squamous epithelium, unlike the lobulated structure of the thymus.
  • D (Spleen): Has red and white pulp regions with arteriole-embedded lymphatic nodules, differing significantly from thymic structure.

Key Takeaways:

  • The thymus is identified by its lobulated structure and the presence of corpuscles of Hassall in the medulla.
  • Distinct cortical and medullary regions are key to its histological differentiation from other lymphoid organs.
  • Understanding these features is crucial for histological identification in examinations.

questions.text: Horizontally oriented white fibre band called outer band of Baillarger is present in which of the following layer of the cerebral cortex?
questions.solution:
• The outer band of Baillarger, which consists of horizontally oriented white fibers, is found in the internal granular layer of the cerebral cortex. This layer is characterized by closely packed stellate cells.

Layers of cerebral cortex:

  • Molecular layer
  • External granular layer
  • External pyramidal layer
  • Internal granular layer
  • Internal pyramidal layer
  • Multiform layer

Why Not Others:

  • A (External Pyramidal Layer): Contains medium-sized pyramidal cells and is not known for the outer band of Baillarger.
  • B (Internal Pyramidal Layer): Contains large pyramidal cells and features the inner band of Baillarger, not the outer one.
  • C (External Granular Layer): Composed of stellate and small pyramidal cells, lacking the specific horizontal white fiber arrangement.

Key Takeaways:

  • The internal granular layer is distinct for housing the outer band of Baillarger, crucial for the cortical structure.
  • Understanding the layering and specific fiber arrangements aids in identifying cerebral cortex features in histological studies.
  • Recognition of these layers is essential in neuroanatomy and histology.

questions.text: Given diagram is showing the microscopic structure of cerebellum. Identify the cells marked with number 2.
questions.solution:
• The cells marked with number 2 in the diagram are Purkinje cells, identifiable by their large, flask-shaped cell bodies located in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellar cortex.
  • This layer is unique as it consists of only one layer of neurons, making it distinct from other brain regions.
  • Purkinje cells are crucial for motor control and coordination; they send inhibitory signals to the deep cerebellar nuclei, regulating motor output.
  • Their dendrites, which extend into the molecular layer, form a complex branching structure that integrates signals from numerous synapses, reflecting their role in processing sensory and motor information.
  • The axons of Purkinje cells descend through the granular layer to reach the white matter, influencing cerebellar output.
  • The neurons of the cerebellar cortex are of five main types:
    • Purkinje cells: forming the layer named after them
    • Granule cells: forming the granular layer
    • Outer (external) stellate cells: lying in molecular layer
    • Basket cells: lying in the molecular layer
    • Golgi cells: present in the granular layer.

Why Not Others:

  • B (Granular Cells): Located in the granular layer, these small neurons lack the distinct morphology of Purkinje cells and do not form a single layer.
  • C (Basket Cells): These cells, found in the molecular layer, have a different structure and primarily function to modulate the activity of Purkinje cells, rather than forming the identifiable layer.
  • D (Golgi Cells): Present in the granular layer, Golgi cells have a unique structure and serve to inhibit granule cells, but they are not flask-shaped like Purkinje cells.

Key Takeaways:

  • Purkinje cells are the defining neurons of the cerebellar cortex, forming a single layer of large, flask-shaped cells crucial for motor coordination.
  • Their extensive dendritic trees allow complex processing of motor signals, highlighting their essential role in balance and coordination.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given slide:
questions.solution:
• The marked structure in the slide is filiform papillae, which are primarily located on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, particularly abundant at the tip.
  • Filiform papillae are characterized by their conical shape, with the tip pointing towards the pharynx, and are covered with keratinized epithelium, providing a rough texture to the tongue's surface.
  • Unlike other types of papillae, filiform papillae do not contain taste buds, making them primarily sensory structures that contribute to the texture of food and the sense of touch on the tongue.
  • They serve a critical role in manipulating food and aiding in the mechanical processing within the oral cavity.

Characteristic features of the different types of lingual papillae:

Why Not Others:

  • A (Fungiform Papillae): These are mushroom-shaped and scattered among filiform papillae, containing a few taste buds on their surface.
  • C (Foliate Papillae): Located on the posterior part of the lateral margins of the tongue, these have many taste buds but are less developed in humans.
  • D (Circumvallate Papillae): These are larger, inverted cone-shaped structures located in front of the sulcus terminalis and contain many taste buds, typically surrounded by a circular trench.

Key Takeaways:

  • Filiform papillae are conical, keratinized projections on the tongue, abundant in the anterior region, and play a role in the mechanical aspect of food processing.
  • They lack taste buds, distinguishing them from other papillae, which are involved in the sensation of taste.

questions.text:
Which of the following features are present in the microscopic structure of the jejunum?
I. Short slender finger like intestinal villi
II. Absence of crypts of Lieberkuhn
III. Absence of Brunner's glands
IV. Absence of Peyer's patches
V. Lined by simple columnar epithelium with goblet cells
questions.solution:
• The microscopic structure of the jejunum is characterized by several key features:
    • Absence of Brunner's glands: These are only present in the duodenum.
    • Absence of Peyer's patches: Peyer's patches are found in the ileum and not in the jejunum.
    • Lined by simple columnar epithelium with goblet cells: This epithelium aids in absorption and secretion, with goblet cells providing mucus for lubrication.

Difference between parts of small intestine:


Why Not Others:

  • I (Short slender finger-like intestinal villi): This feature is characteristic of the ileum, not the jejunum, where villi are longer and club-shaped.
  • II (Absence of crypts of Lieberkuhn): Crypts are present in the jejunum; therefore, this statement is incorrect.
  • V (Absence of crypts of Lieberkuhn): Crypts of Lieberkuhn are present in all parts of the small intestine, including the jejunum.

Key Takeaways:

  • The jejunum lacks Brunner's glands and Peyer's patches, distinguishing it from other parts of the small intestine.

questions.text: All of the following skin receptors are present in the dermis of the skin, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• The Merkel's corpuscle (Option A) is located in the stratum basale of the epidermis, making it the only receptor among the options that is not found in the dermis.
  • In contrast, Meissner's corpuscle, Pacinian corpuscle, and Ruffini's corpuscle are all located in the dermis and play crucial roles in sensation:
    • Meissner's corpuscle: Found in dermal papillae, sensitive to light touch.
    • Pacinian corpuscle: Located deeper in the dermis, responsive to pressure and vibration.
    • Ruffini's corpuscle: Sensitive to skin stretch, also found in the dermis.

Why Not Others:

  • B (Meissner's corpuscle): Present in the dermis, sensitive to light touch.
  • C (Pacinian corpuscle): Located in the dermis, sensitive to deep pressure and vibration.
  • D (Ruffini's corpuscle): Found in the dermis, responds to skin stretch.

Key Takeaways:

  • Merkel's corpuscle is located in the epidermis, distinguishing it from other skin receptors present in the dermis.
  • The skin contains both encapsulated and non-encapsulated receptors, enabling it to respond to various sensory stimuli effectively.

questions.text: Which of the following glands is not a modified sweat gland?
questions.solution:
• The Glands of Zeis (Option D) are modified sebaceous glands, not modified sweat glands, which distinguishes them from the other options listed.
  • The other glands mentioned are classified as modified sweat glands:
    • Mammary gland: Modified apocrine sweat gland responsible for milk production.
    • Ceruminous gland: Located in the external acoustic meatus, produces earwax (cerumen).
    • Glands of Moll: Found in the eyelid, these are modified sweat glands that secrete a substance to lubricate the eye.

Why Not Others:

  • A (Mammary gland): A modified apocrine sweat gland, involved in milk secretion.
  • B (Ceruminous gland): A modified sweat gland that secretes earwax.
  • C (Glands of Moll): Modified sweat glands located in the eyelids.

Key Takeaways:

  • Glands of Zeis are sebaceous glands, not sweat glands, distinguishing them from the other options.
  • Understanding the classification of skin glands is crucial for recognizing their functions and locations in the body.

questions.text: Which of the following part of nephron is not lined by simple cuboidal epithelium?
questions.solution:
• Bowman's capsule (Option A) is lined by simple squamous epithelium, not simple cuboidal epithelium.
  • The renal corpuscle consists of two layers:
    • Parietal layer: Simple squamous epithelium.
    • Visceral layer: Contains podocytes, specialized cells investing the glomerular capillaries.
  • The other nephron parts have a lining of simple cuboidal epithelium:
    • Proximal convoluted tubule (PCT): Lined by simple cuboidal epithelium with microvilli (brush border).
    • Distal convoluted tubule (DCT): Lined by simple cuboidal epithelium (no brush border).
    • Collecting tubules: Also lined by simple cuboidal epithelium.

Why Not Others:

  • B (Proximal convoluted tubule): Lined by simple cuboidal epithelium with microvilli.
  • C (Distal convoluted tubule): Lined by simple cuboidal epithelium (no brush border).
  • D (Collecting tubules): Lined by simple cuboidal epithelium.

Key Takeaways:

  • Bowman's capsule is lined by simple squamous epithelium, distinguishing it from other parts of the nephron.
  • Understanding the epithelial lining of nephron structures is crucial for comprehending their functions in filtration and absorption.

choices.text: It is having a star shaped lumen
It is lined by transitional epithelium
The lamina propria is rich in reticular fibers
It consists of smooth muscle fibers arranged into two layers in the upper two-third and three layers in the lower one-third part of the ureter

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about the microscopic structure of ureter, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Ureter Structure:
    • Ureters are muscular tubes transporting urine from the renal pelvis to the urinary bladder through peristaltic contractions.
    • The ureter wall consists of three layers:
      • Mucosa:
        • Lined by transitional epithelium (Option B), allowing for stretching.
        • The lamina propria is rich in elastic fibres, not reticular fibres, making Option C false.
        • The mucosa forms longitudinal folds, creating a star-shaped lumen (Option A) in cross-section.
      • Muscle Coat:
        • Composed of smooth muscle arranged in two layers in the upper two-thirds: an inner longitudinal and an outer circular layer (Option D).
        • In the lower one-third, an additional outer longitudinal layer is present.
      • Adventitia:
        • The outermost layer containing loose connective tissue with blood vessels, lymphatics, and nerves.

Why Not Others

  • Option A: True, as the mucosa's longitudinal folds create a star-shaped lumen.
  • Option B: True, the ureter is lined with transitional epithelium, allowing for flexibility.
  • Option D: True, the arrangement of smooth muscle fibres is correctly described as having two layers in the upper two-thirds and three layers in the lower one-third.

Key Takeaways

  • The lamina propria in the ureter contains elastic fibres, not reticular fibres, which makes Option C incorrect.
  • Ureters are characterized by:
    • Transitional epithelium lining.
    • Star-shaped lumen due to mucosal folds.
    • Smooth muscle structure allowing peristaltic movement.

questions.text: According to lining epithelium, which of the following structures is different from others?
questions.solution:
• Epididymis (Option A): Lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia, essential for sperm maturation.
  • Ejaculatory duct (Option B): Unique as it is lined by simple columnar epithelium, differing from the others.
  • Vas deferens (Option C): Also lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium with stereocilia, similar to epididymis.
  • Seminal vesicle (Option D): Contains pseudostratified low columnar epithelium, consistent with the other tubular structures except for the ejaculatory duct.
  • Lining epithelium of :
    • Epididymis: Pseudostratified columnar
    • Ejaculatory duct: Simple columnar
    • Vas deferens: Pseudostratified columnar
    • Seminal vesicle: Pseudostratified columnar
    • Penile urethra: stratified squamous

Why Not Others:

  • A (Epididymis): Lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium, not different.
  • C (Vas deferens): Similar epithelium to epididymis; therefore, not different.
  • D (Seminal vesicle): Also pseudostratified, aligning with the others.

Key Takeaways:

  • The ejaculatory duct is uniquely lined by simple columnar epithelium, differentiating it from structures lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium.
  • Understanding the lining of these reproductive structures is vital for histological identification and functional comprehension.

choices.text: Preparing ground for the reception of blastocyst for implantation
Presence of simple straight tubular glands with narrow lumen
Presence of highly cellular and nonoedematous stroma

questions.text: All of following are true about the proliferative phase of the endometrium, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Lined by simple columnar epithelium (Option A): This is true for the proliferative phase, as the endometrium is lined with simple columnar epithelium.
  • Preparing ground for the reception of blastocyst for implantation (Option B): False for the proliferative phase; this preparation occurs during the secretory phase.
  • Presence of simple straight tubular glands with narrow lumen (Option C): Accurate description for the proliferative phase, as the glands are simple and straight.
  • Presence of highly cellular and nonoedematous stroma (Option D): True, as the stroma during the proliferative phase is highly cellular and nonoedematous.

Structural differences in the endometrium of proliferative phase and secretory phase:

Why Not Others:

  • A: True, as the lining is indeed simple columnar.
  • C: True, as the presence of straight tubular glands is characteristic of the proliferative phase.
  • D: True, the stroma is nonoedematous and cellular during this phase.

Key Takeaways:

  • During the proliferative phase, the endometrium is characterized by simple columnar epithelium and simple straight tubular glands.
  • The preparation for implantation occurs during the secretory phase, where the endometrium becomes succulent and oedematous.

questions.text: Which of the following cell is seen in the olfactory mucosa, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Lined by simple columnar epithelium (Option A): This is true for the proliferative phase, as the endometrium is lined with simple columnar epithelium.
  • Preparing ground for the reception of blastocyst for implantation (Option B): False for the proliferative phase; this preparation occurs during the secretory phase.
  • Presence of simple straight tubular glands with narrow lumen (Option C): Accurate description for the proliferative phase, as the glands are simple and straight.
  • Presence of highly cellular and nonoedematous stroma (Option D): True, as the stroma during the proliferative phase is highly cellular and nonoedematous.

Key points:

  • Cells of olfactory mucosa:
    • Olfactory cells
    • Basal cells
    • Sustentacular cells
  • Cells of respiratory mucosa:
    • Brush cells
    • Goblet cells
    • Ciliated cells
    • Granule cells
    • Basal cells

Why Not Others:

  • A: True, as the lining is indeed simple columnar.
  • C: True, as the presence of straight tubular glands is characteristic of the proliferative phase.
  • D: True, the stroma is nonoedematous and cellular during this phase.

Key Takeaways:

  • During the proliferative phase, the endometrium is characterized by simple columnar epithelium and simple straight tubular glands.
  • The preparation for implantation occurs during the secretory phase, where the endometrium becomes succulent and oedematous.

choices.text: Over secretion of mucous in the bronchus
Enlarged alveoli with destruction of interalveolar septum
Widen and thickened wall of the bronchi

questions.text: The emphysema is characterised by:
questions.solution:
• Over secretion of mucous in the bronchus (Option A): True for chronic bronchitis, not emphysema.
  • Spasmodic narrowing of the bronchi (Option B): Characteristic of bronchial asthma, not emphysema.
  • Enlarged alveoli with destruction of interalveolar septum (Option C): True for emphysema; it causes destruction and enlargement of alveoli.
  • Widen and thickened wall of the bronchi (Option D): Related to bronchiectasis, not emphysema.
  • Emphysema:
    • Cigarette smoking may also lead to emphysema.
    • It is a condition in which the lung alveoli are enlarged with destruction of interalveolar septum.
    • It is caused by impairment of synthesis of elastic fibres and other components of septum.

Why Not Others:

  • B: True for asthma due to airway hyperresponsiveness causing spasmodic narrowing.
  • C: Accurate for emphysema; it is characterized by alveolar enlargement and destruction.
  • D: True for bronchiectasis, where inflammation leads to thickened bronchial walls.

Key Takeaways:

  • Emphysema is characterized by enlarged alveoli and destruction of interalveolar septa due to loss of elastic tissue.
  • Chronic bronchitis involves overproduction of mucus, while bronchial asthma is marked by spasmodic airway narrowing.

questions.text: In the microscopic structure of retina, the synaptic layer formed by the axons of rods and cones with the dendrites of bipolar neurons and processes of horizontal cells is known as:
questions.solution:
• Outer nuclear layer (Option A): Contains cell bodies of rods and cones, not synaptic connections.
  • Outer plexiform layer (Option B): Correct answer; formed by synapses between axons of rods/cones and dendrites of bipolar neurons and horizontal cells.
  • Inner nuclear layer (Option C): Contains cell bodies of bipolar, horizontal, and amacrine cells, not synaptic connections.
  • Inner plexiform layer (Option D): Composed of synapses between axons of bipolar cells and dendrites of ganglionic neurons.

Why Not Others:

  • A: Incorrect as it refers to cell bodies, not synapses.
  • C: Incorrect as it includes various cell bodies, no synaptic layer.
  • D: Refers to a different synaptic layer involving bipolar and ganglionic neurons.

Key Takeaways:

  • The outer plexiform layer is crucial for synaptic interactions in the retina, linking photoreceptor outputs to bipolar and horizontal cells.
  • Understanding retinal layers aids in comprehending visual signal processing and the organization of the retina.

questions.text: The figure is showing the structure of chochlear canal. Identify the marked cavity.
questions.solution:
• Scala vestibuli (1): Located above the basilar membrane, continuous with the vestibule at the base of the cochlea.
  • Scala media (2): Also known as the cochlear duct, located between the basilar and vestibular membranes, contains endolymph.
  • Scala tympani (3): Located below the basilar membrane, opens into the middle ear via the round window.

Why Not Others:

  • A: Incorrect arrangement of scalae.
  • B: Misidentifies scalae locations.
  • C: Incorrect order; scala media is misidentified as scala tympani.

Key Takeaways:

  • The cochlear canal comprises three distinct parts: scala vestibuli, scala media, and scala tympani, essential for auditory function.
  • Understanding these structures aids in grasping the mechanics of sound transmission and hearing processes.

questions.text: Identify the endocrine gland shown in the given diagram:
questions.solution:
• Thyroid Gland Characteristics:
    • Composed of follicles lined by cuboidal epithelium.
    • Each follicle contains a homogenous pink colloid (thyroglobulin).
    • Parafollicular cells are present around the follicles.
    • Contains connective tissue and blood vessels between follicles.

Structure of thyroid gland:

Why Not Others:

  • A (Parathyroid Gland): Characterized by chief cells and oxyphil cells, lacking the follicular structure of thyroid.
  • C (Pituitary Gland): Contains distinct cell types (acidophils, basophils, chromophobes) arranged in cords, no follicles.
  • D (Adrenal Gland): Composed of distinct cortical zones and medullary structures, with layered organization, not follicular.

Key Takeaways:

  • The thyroid gland is essential for hormone production, and its follicular structure is key for identifying it microscopically.
  • Understanding glandular structure aids in recognizing their function in the endocrine system.

choices.text: Zona glomerulosa, Zona reticularis, Zona fasciculata
Zona fasciculata, Zona reticularis, Zona glomerulosa
Zona reticularis, Zona glomerulosa, Zona fasciculata
Zona glomerulosa, Zona fasciculata, Zona reticularis

questions.text: In the relation to superficial to deep, which of the following is a correct sequence of the layers of adrenal cortex?
questions.solution:
• The adrenal cortex has three histological zones arranged from superficial to deep:
    • Zona glomerulosa: Outermost layer, secretes mineralocorticoids (primarily aldosterone).
    • Zona fasciculata: Middle layer, responsible for secreting glucocorticoids (mainly cortisol).
    • Zona reticularis: Innermost layer, secretes small amounts of androgens and glucocorticoids.

Why Not Others:

  • A (Zona glomerulosa, Zona reticularis, Zona fasciculata): Incorrect order; reticularis is not above fasciculata.
  • B (Zona fasciculata, Zona reticularis, Zona glomerulosa): Incorrect; glomerulosa is the outermost layer.
  • C (Zona reticularis, Zona glomerulosa, Zona fasciculata): Incorrect; reticularis is the innermost layer.

Key Takeaways:

  • The correct sequence of adrenal cortex layers is essential for understanding their functional roles in hormone secretion.
  • Proper identification aids in recognizing the structure and function of the adrenal gland in the endocrine system.
